Award.AwardTitle: CAREER: Increasing the Effectiveness of Mineral Additives in Concrete Through Novel Particle Characterization

Division.LongName: Div Of Civil, Mechanical, & Manufact Inn

Award.AbstractNarration:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project will develop a strong research program to increase the use of supplementary cementitious materials (SCMs) as construction binders in concrete through new levels of chemical characterization. Since SCMs are unwanted material streams from different industrial processes, there is much variability in the materials. The research will use novel particle characterization techniques developed by the PIs research group to better understand, quantify, improve and increase the use of SCMs as construction binders. The objectives are: i) characterize SCMs by coupling particle size and chemistry, through 3D particle chemical mapping, rapid investigation with autonomous scanning electron microscopy, and bulk chemistry, ii) quantify the short term and long term performance of SCMs as concrete binders through strength, permeability, chemical shrinkage and heat of hydration changes over time, iii) understand the mechanisms by which different chemical phases in the SCM impact performance as a concrete binder.

Concrete is the second most used commodity in the world. The use of SCMs in concrete has the ability to improve the strength, durability, economy and sustainability of concrete. Current use of SCMs in concrete is limited because of the high variability of the material. This research will provide new fundamental knowledge of chemical phases, their distribution, and how these phases react with hydrating cement paste. Ultimately these interactions will be used to understand how this impacts the properties and performance of the concrete containing the SCM from a few hours to over a year. Furthermore, the techniques established in this research will be useful for a number of applications that require complex particle characterization and allowing time resolved measurements of their reactions and structural changes in different environments. These methods can be applied to biomaterials, pharmaceuticals, geo-materials, polymers, industrial waste products. The educational activities will also increase the awareness level of STEM fields with underrepresented elementary students through the establishment of an after school mentoring program and the creation of online teaching modules.

ProgramReference.Text: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

POR.DRECONTENT:
This Faculty Early Career Development (CAREER) project developed a strong research program to increase the use of supplementary cementitious materials (SCMs) as construction binders in concrete through new levels of chemical characterization.  Since SCMs are unwanted material streams from different industrial processes, there is much variability in the materials.  The research team used novel particle characterization techniques developed by the PIs research group to better understand, quantify, improve and increase the use of SCMs as construction binders.  This was done by i) characterizing SCMs by coupling particle size and chemistry, through 3D particle chemical mapping, rapid investigation with autonomous scanning electron microscopy, and bulk chemistry, ii) quantifying the short term and long term performance of SCMs within concrete binders over time, iii) understanding the mechanisms by which different chemical phases in the SCM impact performance as a concrete binder. 

 

Concrete is the second most used commodity in the world.  The use of SCMs in concrete has the ability to improve the strength, durability, economy and sustainability of concrete.  Current use of SCMs in concrete is limited because of the high variability of the material.  This research provides the basis for a new classification system to predict the performance of SCMs within concrete from a few hours to over a year.  This classification can allow for better predictions of SCM usage.  This, in turn, can allow for a greater volume of these materials to be used in concrete mixtures with better prediction of their performance.  This can improve the sustainability, performance, and durability of concrete.  Which can help produce longer lasting and more reliable infrastructure.

 

Furthermore, the techniques established in this research are useful for a number of applications that require complex particle characterization and allowing time-resolved measurements of their reactions and structural changes in different environments.  These methods are being applied to biomaterials, pharmaceuticals, geo-materials, polymers, and industrial waste products.    The educational activities were shown to successfully increase the awareness level of STEM fields with underrepresented elementary students through the establishment of an after school mentoring program and the creation of online teaching modules.  The curriculum was used to train over 800 upper elementary students in Oklahoma and the lessons have been shared on YouTube more than 107,000 times.  The effectiveness of the lessons was investigated and shown to statistically improve the knowledge level of necessary skills for engineering careers.

This can improve the sustainability, performance, and durability of concrete. Which can help produce longer lasting and more reliable infrastructure.
